captions.text:
JAMES GRIME: Well, we're going
to talk about illegal numbers.

And when I heard that there
were these things, illegal

numbers, that some numbers were
illegal, I was shocked
and surprised as well.

Today, in the modern world,
numbers are used as keys to
encrypt secret information.

They're used to encrypt or
protect DVDs as well, so that

you can't illegally copy
films off a DVD.

You need to protect
those keys.

So if you distribute those
secret keys, those secret

numbers, this is
a real problem.

And some people are claiming
that it would be illegal to
distribute those numbers.

And so it's the number itself
that becomes illegal.

And there are some other
problems as well because you

can consider a digital
photograph or a computer

program as simply as a string
of binary digits.

And then a string of binary
digits is a number.

So there is a number
for a photograph
or a computer program.

So if you distribute the number,
you could sort of work

out the original computer
program or the image.

And if that's an illegal
computer program that's

hacking data, then does the
number become illegal itself?

To show you the problem, I
thought, I don't want to write

down any illegal numbers
in this video.

So I thought I'd come up
with my own example.

So imagine if we decide
to trademark the name
Numberphile.

So we're going to write down
Numberphile first of all.

I'm going to use capital letters
because I like the

number we got at
the end better.

So I'm going to use capital
letters for Numberphile.

I've written out the
word Numberphile.

Now, each character in ASCII has
a binary representation.
So let's do that.

So for the capital
N, 01001110.

And now I can do it up
for the U as well.
But I'd better get them right.
You know they'll notice.
The H, 0101.
Whoo.

So that's Numberphile written
as a binary string.

So if we joined all that
together, that's just one big
binary number.

Do you want to know what
that number is?

So that number in
decimal is 94--

So this is Numberphile
written as a number,
the Numberphile number.

And if I catch any of you
distributing this number about

on the internet, right, you're
infringing our trademark, OK?

Don't let me catch
you doing that.
There is a serious problem.

So I'm a mathematician,
not a lawyer.

I can't talk about the full
implications of this.

I'm hoping that I am giving
you the extreme case, a
simplified extreme case.

But at the very least, this is
what we're trying to avoid,

that numbers themselves
become illegal.

That's what we're trying to
avoid because the implications
of it are bizarre.

So you can't distribute
these illegal numbers.

But then can you distribute
the number minus 1?

Or if I write down a list of
numbers where some of them are

illegal, am I allowed to
distribute that list?

I hope that it's distributing
the number and the intent to
infringe copyright.

But the extreme case is what
we're trying to avoid.
It has become a problem.

In recent years, there have been
a couple of cases where

people like Sony have sued
people for distributing their

secret encryption keys for
their PlayStation 3.

And the Motion Picture
Association of America have

forced people to remove posts
that were encryption keys for

their DVDs, which people were
using to illegally copy DVDs.
This annoyed the internet.

Ah, the internet-- this
annoyed them.

So then they started to
taunt these people.

So what they started
to do next is they
would take these numbers.

And to taunt, they would then
turn these numbers into
hexadecimal.

And hexadecimal defines
colors as well.

So then they become
illegal colors.
If I do this for Numberphile--
I've worked this out already.

This number, which is 94
septillion and something, if I
write it in hexadecimal--

so this is the Numberphile
number written as hexadecimal.

Now, these groups here
define a color.

Each of those groups define a
color, and then we've got a
little bit extra.

So what you can do then is you
can make something like this.

So these are the three colors
defined by the Numberphile

number plus that little
extra bit.

And then if you start posting
this around on internet

forums, again, you'll be
infringing our trademark, and

we'll be round to come
round your house.

And we're going to stamp on
all your favorite toys.

So I don't want to catch
any of you doing that.

BRADY HARAN: So here are some
of those taunting protests

that James referred
to in the video.

These are colored flags based
on the DVD and PlayStation
encoding numbers.

Of course, another issue we
didn't touch on this video

surrounds copyrighting
of numbers like pi.

And there's a lot of stories
involving that, too.

Maybe we'll talk about
that another time.

A quick thanks to James Clewett,
who actually turned

the Mona Lisa into zeros
and ones for me.

And if you'd like to read more
about that, I'll put a link in
the video description.

And lastly, because we're a
lot more relaxed about our

illegal numbers here at
Numberphile, James Grime and I

have put that piece of paper
used in the video on eBay in

case anyone wants to get
their hands on it.

Again, links in the
video description.
Thanks for watching.

And we'll be back with
more videos soon.

comments.text: Intent is everything﻿
comments.author: rooneye

comments.text:
So now I will use the number of pi as my number. And now everyone who use 
this number for he's purposes like counting the area of a circle or so one 
will be punished. Do You see, what the problem is. If this will be, anyone 
can say: x is a illegal number without saying, why, because then the secret 
will be no secret more. Now everyone can say: x or y has not to be used for 
any purposes at all. It can't be, do You imagine why? Because then no one 
can be sure that he use only legal numbers. And even with this example of 
the number of "Numberphile" this will be so. But the next is: If You cannot 
use the number then You cannot use the base itself. Also I cannot use the 
word "numberphile" itself. And then, if any othe say: "bird", or "hunger" 
is my word, You can't use the words ever. The same as the numbers. Then You 
can't use any word sat all without being sure that they are all legal. The 
complete private possession of imaginations like numbers or words is - in 
my mind - illegal itself. Despite of the fact that You can't punish all of 
the people who use them, it's impossible. So there is not one number, who 
is real illegal.﻿

comments.text:
the smallest copyrighted code I found was 
"IEFBR14 START
USING IEFBR14,15
BR GO
DC AL1(L'ID)
ID DC C'IEFBR14'
DS 0H
GO SR 15,15
BR 14
END IEFBR14"
which ends up being 110 bytes. Even this smallest code would be 264 digits 
long. there's not much chance you'll stumble on this by accident﻿

comments.author: Dean Kenneth Korstjens

comments.text:
There are 26 digits in the decimal version of the Numberphile number. 
Therefore the odds of a random 26-digit number having the same sequence as 
the Numberphile number is one in 10^26.

But the digits of Pi are infinite and non-repeating, therefore the number 
Pi contains within its digits an infinite number of 26-digit sequences that 
are identical to the Numberphile number.

So doesn't that mean the Numberphile number is already in the public 
domain?   :-)﻿

comments.author: jan christian Frodahl

comments.text:
My instinct here, keeping in mind I'm not a mathematician nor a lawyer (ie, 
can someone check this please?), would be that encryption keys would be 
defined as "a device or method by which certain data may be unlocked", 
which looks suspiciously like a patent claim (ie, I would argue that the 
difference between an encryption key and a physical one is none (and most 
people just carry around their private keys in the open in an easily 
readable format! How insecure!)). Patents operate by legally protecting the 
people who publicly publish how their device works. If you don't publish, 
that's a Trade Secret, which does not carry those same protections. 

... That would imply that patents and copyrights are equivalent?

Trademarks, at least, work differently, but they come with release clauses 
and inherent subjectivity, so it would become almost trivial to break those 
too. ﻿

comments.text:
If a number is *illegal* then it needs to be stated in a legal statute or 
Act of Parliament...

But once the Act is published there's a whole list of illegal numbers 
publicly available, tempting hackers to find out what they mean.  

In the meantime, I've now officially copyrighted the number 2018. In three 
years time I'm going to be very rich!﻿

comments.author: TheMetadaemon

comments.text:
+TheMetadaemon While that would be certainly sensible, but I think you will 
find our society is far to often very silly and not sensible. As a 
chemistry nerd, I will give you my example.


I am not a terrorist, I don't have ties to terrorist groups or any intent 
to cause harm to anyone. Yet if I am found with say, ETN, without a permit, 
then I am committing a crime. Does it have to be more than just the ETN? 
No, they will definitely charge on just that. Same thing with illegal drugs.
comments.author: MrLittlelawyer

comments.text:
+MrLittlelawyer It needs to be more than just the number. It's the likely 
use of the number that determines it's legality. For example a number 
that's found to represent an illegal image file on a computer would be 
illegal. The same number appearing in a complex mathematical equation for 
predicting earthquakes would be legal.
